FacilityStr1: 1/2 Mile So. of Hwy 200 on 4th Ave.

_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Response test of chlorine gas monitors
_prev_prog_2.Description: The chlorine process at the Dodge Pumping Station is a system used to inject chlorine into raw water for the purpose of disinfection. The chlorine building is a separate building from that of the main pumping station building. One ton chlorine containers, are located in the chlorine building. Two containers are fitted with gas regulators, which are attached by vacuum lines to an automatic switch-over. From the switch-over, the vacuum line runs approx. 200 feet under ground to the main pump building. The chlorine gas is then injected into a 30 inch raw water transmission line via the automatic chlorine controller. Ammonium Sulfate in solution is pumped into the raw water transmission line just prior to the point of chlorine injection; this forms chloramines used as a disinfection. The average gas flow is approx. 50 pounds per day. The system is designed to shut down if there is a vacuum leak in the system or if there is a gas leak detection.

_exec_summary.SummaryText: Southwest Water Authority (SWA) is a political subdivision of the North Dakota State Water Commission, established for the purpose of supplying water to the southwest region of North Dakota. The SWA delivers an estimated 5.9 million gallons of treated water per day to its customers.  Because of the amount of chlorine stored and used in the water treatment process at various locations within our water system, we as management/operators are required to submit a Risk Management Plan (RMP) to the EPA under 40 CRF Part 68-Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions ruling. Currently we have three locations that use chlorine. With our RMP program in place, we will store up to four chlorine containers, (8,000 lbs.) at each location. Our locations include: the Dickinson Water Treatment Plant (DWTP), the OMND Water Treatment Plant (OMNDWTP) and the Dodge Pumping Station (DPS). SWA is in compliance with the EPA's Community Right-To-Know Act (EPCRA). Each year since the reporting year of 1992, the WTP has submitted to the state and local emergency response authorities, documentation of the hazardous chemicals used and stored at both our locations. All senior operators employed with SWA are trained in chlorine safety and are well versed in the operational aspects of the chlorine/ ammonia disinfection process. Novice operators are assisted by senior operators with chlorine processes, operations, and maintenance of equipment.  On-going training sessions for chlorine safety as well as other safety training is and will be conducted on a regular basis. All senior operators engaged in the maintenance of the chlorine process equipment are well informed as to the equipment mechanics, calibration and testing. The RMP is well received and is an important part of the safety program for SWA. SWA has a written emergency response plan and the RMP is used in conjunction with this plan. SWA has an excellent chlorine accident history. Our records show that there has never been a chlorine related ac

cident or incident involving injury or significant property damage. In coordination with the Stark County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC), the Dickinson Fire Department will act as the emergency response team for the DWTP. In coordination with the Dunn County LEPC; the Halliday District Fire Department will act as the emergency response team for the DPS. In coordination with the Mercer County LEPC, the Zap Fire Department will act as the emergency response team for the OMNDWTP.  In the event of a chlorine leak detection, via chlorine gas monitors and computer telemetry, the operators will respond to the alarm in accordance with our Risk Management Program.
